subj-group.subject: Health and the use of registries

title-group.article-title: Large differences between patients with acute myocardial infarction included in two Swedish health registers

article-meta.aff: 1Karolinska Institutet, Department of Clinical Sciences, Danderyd Hospital, Division of Cardiovascular Medicine, Stockholm, Sweden
2Department of Medical and Health Sciences, Division of Cardiology, University Hospital, Linköping, Sweden
3National board of Health and Welfare, Unit for Statistics on Public Health and Social Care, Stockholm, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: Dr Sara Aspberg, Karolinska Institutet, Department of Clinical Sciences, Danderyd Hospital, Division of Cardiovascular Medicine, 182 88 Stockholm, Sweden. E-mail: sara.aspberg@ds.se

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 the Nordic Societies of Public Health
permissions.copyright-holder: Associations of Public Health in the Nordic Countries Regions

abstract.p: Background: Acute myocardial infarction (MI) is a leading cause for morbidity and mortality in Sweden. We aimed to compare patients with an acute MI included in the Register of information and knowledge about Swedish heart intensive care admissions (RIKS-HIA, now included in the register Swedeheart) and in the Swedish statistics of acute myocardial infarctions (S-AMI). Methods: Population based register study including RIKS-HIA, S-AMI, the National patient register and the Cause of death register. Odds ratios were determined by logistic regression analysis. Results: From 2001 to 2007, 114,311 cases in RIKS-HIA and 198,693 cases in S-AMI were included with a discharge diagnosis of an acute MI. Linkage was possible for 110,958 cases. These cases were younger, more often males, had fewer concomitant diseases and were more often treated with invasive coronary artery procedures than patients included in S-AMI only. There were substantial regional differences in proportions of patients reported to RIKS-HIA. Conclusions: Approximately half of all patients with an acute MI were included in RIKS-HIA. They represented a relatively more healthy population than patients included in S-AMI only. S-AMI covered almost all patients with an acute MI but had limited information about the patients. Used in combination, these two registers can give better prerequisites for improved quality of care of all patients with acute coronary syndromes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Acute myocardial infarction (MI) remains a leading cause for morbidity and mortality in Sweden and other countries, although mortality has decreased during the last 20 years [1–4]. During this period of time, diagnostic tools and treatments for acute coronary syndromes have seen major changes. Several Swedish nationwide health registers of high quality provide good possibilities to follow and describe such changes in epidemiology and clinical practice. Among these are the Register of information and knowledge about Swedish heart intensive care admissions (RIKS-HIA, since 2009 included in the Swedeheart register) and the Swedish statistics of acute myocardial infarctions (S-AMI), both described below.

The S-AMI [4] is a register based on linkage between the National patient register and the Cause of death register. The National patient register contains information on all hospitalizations with discharge diagnoses in Sweden since 1987 [5], whereas the Cause of death register includes all deaths in Sweden with supposed cause of decease [6]. RIKS-HIA started as a regional register in 1991 [3]. It includes patients who have been hospitalized in coronary (CCU) or intensive care units (ICU). The register has developed gradually and today all 73 hospitals in Sweden taking care of patients with acute coronary syndromes in a CCU or ICU participate. A main purpose of the register is to improve quality of care and to increase compliance to national guidelines concerning the treatment of patients with acute coronary syndromes. This is achieved by following temporal trends within the hospital and by comparisons between hospitals, which are made public and available to health care providers, decision makers and health economists.

One potential limitation of RIKS-HIA is that several patients with acute coronary syndromes are hospitalized in other units than a CCU/ICU for various reasons, e.g. old age, concomitant diseases, or logistic reasons within the hospital organization. The ambition nowadays is also to include patients with an acute MI hospitalized in other wards than the CCU/ICU. Hospitals have the opportunity to report patients who are taken care of outside the CCU/ICU to RIKS-HIA, but use this opportunity differently. However, some information about these patients can be obtained from S-AMI. Knowledge about these patients is important, in order to provide for a correct description of patients with an acute MI in Sweden, and to ascertain adequate care of all patients with an acute coronary syndrome. Thus, the aim of this study was to examine similarities and potential differences of patients with an acute MI included in RIKS-HIA and in the population based S-AMI.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: All patients with a discharge diagnosis of an acute MI and who were included in RIKS-HIA during the time period from 1 January 2001 to 1 January 2007 were selected. Thereby we identified 114,311 hospitalizations in a CCU or ICU for an acute MI. In S-AMI, all patients by definition have a diagnosis of an acute MI. A total of 198,693 cases were included in S-AMI during the same time period. In the S-AMI register all hospitalizations due to an MI within 28 days after the index diagnosis are supposed to be related to the incident case. This is due to the ICD-classification, and thus no new incident cases are counted during the first month. RIKS-HIA, however, counts every hospitalization as a new MI. To avoid matching several times for the same event, only one match per 28 days was allowed, based on the incidence date in S-AMI.

Linkage between the two registers was made using the personal identification number given to everyone living in Sweden, and widely used in health care. Linkage was possible for 110,958 cases (matched, 55.3%), 2893 cases (1.4%) could be identified in RIKS-HIA only, and 79,836 (39.8%) in S-AMI only. Further analysis showed that among the cases found in S-AMI only, 7097 (3.5%) actually were registered in RIKS-HIA but under other diagnoses. Thus, we identified four groups of cases. Each group was characterized according to age, sex, mortality and to level of care in different county councils. Comorbidity (see Table I) was obtained by linkage to the National patient register. Information about mortality for the cases included in RIKS-HIA was only obtained by linkage between RIKS-HIA and the Cause of death register. Linkage failed for 12 patients due to wrongly registered death dates.

fn.p: ICD-10 is used in Sweden since 1997

sec.p: In order to obtain a maximum number of participating hospitals, the analyses concerning age, sex, comorbidity, hospitals and county councils were performed in 2005 and 2006 only.

Statistical analysis was made by logistic regression after adjustments for age, sex and comorbidity as described in the text. Data are presented as odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Descriptive and analytic statistics were performed using Logistic Procedures in SAS version 9.1 (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA).

sec.title: General
sec.p: The degree of coverage (that is, the proportion of patients included in both registers) was around 55% with a slow increase from 53.6% in 2001 to 56.2% in 2006. The degree of coverage by year and sex is shown in Table II.

caption.p: Degree of covering by year and sex.

tr.th: Cases in both registers but under different diagnoses

sec.title: Age and sex
sec.p: Cases taken care of in wards other than the CCU/ICU were on average older than the rest of the population. The (very few) oldest patients, 105 to 108 years of age, all belonged to this group. Of cases included in S-AMI only, 56.2% were older than 80 years, as compared to 28.6% of patients included in both registers. In the total population of cases with an acute MI, 56.7% were younger than 80 years of age. In Table III, the likelihood for cases with an acute MI to be hospitalized in a CCU/ICU is given according to age.

caption.p: Hospitalizations in CCU or ICU according to age.

fn.p: Probability for cases with an acute MI to be hospitalized in other units than a CCU/ICU, according to age in five year classes, and adjusted for sex and comorbidities. Age 40 to 44 years serve as reference.

sec.p: There were 41.9% women in the total population. A larger proportion of women, 46.3%, were included in S-AMI only. Among the cases who were included in RIKS-HIA only and among those who matched, the proportions of women were lower, 35.3% and 37.4%, respectively. Also within cases up to and including 80 years of age, where women constituted 33.4% of the population, 38.3% of the cases included in S-AMI only were women, while they constituted 31.6% in the matched group. Analyses of men and women with no known severe comorbidity (as defined in Table I) revealed that 63.9% of the women and 74.8% of the men were treated in a CCU/ICU. The odds ratio for women with an acute MI being hospitalized outside of a CCU/ICU was 1.25 (95% confidence interval 1.21–1.30), after adjustments for age and comorbidity.

sec.title: Comorbidity and treatment
sec.p: The comorbidity of the cases is summarized in Table IV. The cases included in S-AMI only showed more comorbidity in every studied respect, with the exception of valvular heart disease.

caption.p: Comorbidities prior to or at the same time as the myocardial infarction.

fn.p: The final analysis examined the different comorbidities and risk of hospitalization in other units than CCU/ICU after adjustments for sex and age.
Up to 3 years prior to the myocardial infarction

sec.p: The differences in age and comorbidity between the groups are reflected in differences concerning invasive procedures. Among the cases included in S-AMI only, 2.0% had undergone percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI) within 30 days of the event, and 2.5% within 1 year. Among those included in both registers, 18.4% had undergone PCI 30 days after, and 20.0% 1 year after the MI. Similar differences applied to coronary artery bypass grafting. The proportion of cases with bypass grafting done within 30 days and included in S-AMI only was 0.9%, and within 1 year 1.5%, whereas corresponding numbers for the matched cases were 3.5% and 5.4%.

sec.title: Level of care and county council
sec.p: The majority of the cases were hospitalized in departments of internal medicine or cardiology, 71.3% and 22.9%, respectively, among the cases who matched, and 68.7% and 5.3% among the cases included in S-AMI only. These results may reflect hospital organization, since only the largest hospitals have separate departments of cardiology, while others have their CCU included in departments of internal medicine. Some cases were treated in departments of emergency care (3.6%), infectious diseases (4.2%), and geriatric care (6.3%). Around 10% of the cases were identified in departments of surgery (patients hospitalized in thoracic surgery departments excluded). Among these, 15% to 20% were transferred to CCU/ICU and subsequently included in RIKS-HIA.

There were marked regional differences between county councils in the proportion of cases reported to RIKS-HIA, from 24.3% to 83.0%. There were also large differences between hospitals (also when excluding hospitals that did not report at all, or only recently had begun to report, patients to RIKS-HIA), from 76.6% of cases not included in RIKS-HIA to 85.5% of cases included in both registers (data not shown).

sec.title: Case fatality
sec.p: Case fatality at 28 days and 1 year was about two-fold higher among the cases hospitalized outside the CCU/ICU (Table V). Case fatality in the different county councils also differed markedly (data not shown).

tr.th: Cases in both registers but under different diagnoses

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study compares two Swedish nation-wide registers, one including subjects with a hospital discharge diagnosis of an acute MI (that is, S-AMI) and the other including patients hospitalized in a CCU/ICU, most of them due to acute coronary syndromes (that is, RIKS-HIA). We have previously shown excellent validity of diagnoses in S-AMI [7] and RIKS-HIA [8]. Altogether, our results show that just about every second patient in Sweden with an acute MI was hospitalized in a CCU/ICU during the studied years. These patients, compared to those not treated in such units, were younger and more likely to be male, showed less comorbidity, were more often subject to coronary artery interventional procedures, and had a favourable prognosis. Similar results were found in a smaller regional study comparing patients with acute MI during 2005 included in the Swedish register LOMAS (Longitudinal Multilevel Analysis in Scania) with patients included in RIKS-HIA [9].

One major finding is that RIKS-HIA included just 57% of all patients with an acute MI as discharge diagnosis, while almost all (99%) of the cases with a MI were identified by S-AMI. There was, however, a trend for better covering of patients in RIKS-HIA with an acute MI over the studied years (from 54% in 2001 to 56% in 2006). Indeed, in recent years, Swedeheart also regularly links to S-AMI to provide better information about the degree of coverage.

We found more comorbidity in cases included in S-AMI only (Table IV). Valvular heart disease was the only comorbid condition equally common among the cases included in both registers as among those included in S-AMI only. This may be plausible, as valvular heart disease may worsen heart failure in association with an acute MI and make the patient more likely to be referred to a CCU/ICU. However, a prior MI or a diagnosis of heart failure did not increase the likelihood to be treated in a CCU/ICU. Among the patients with comorbidity, there are probably cases where it would be unethical to provide intensive cardiac care, while others may have symptomatic and prognostic benefit from more intense care. Nevertheless, patients included in S-AMI only presented with more comorbidity and were more likely to have a worse prognosis than their counterpart in RIKS-HIA.

Case fatality both at day 28 and at 1 year was approximately two-fold higher in patients included in S-AMI only, as compared to matched cases treated in a CCU/ICU. Our results are in agreement with findings from a smaller register study by Herlitz and colleagues [10], and suggest that the prognosis of patients with an acute MI treated in a CCU/ICU does not reflect the prognosis of the entire population of patients with a discharge diagnosis of an acute MI.

We observed more women among the patients included in S-AMI only. This could be explained by age and/or comorbidity since women are on average older and have more concomitant diseases than men when they develop coronary heart disease [3,4,11]. However, the difference remained when age and comorbidity was taken into account, and also when men and women with no other known comorbidity up to and including 80 years of age, were compared. Our results extend observations by Herlitz and collaborators, who concluded that women with an acute MI were less frequently referred to treatment in a CCU [12]. It is possible that the difference in gender referral rate can be explained by differences in severity of the acute MI, that is, men would have more severe MI than women, and thus more often be referred to a CCU/ICU. In this study, it was not possible to control for severity of the MI. Of note, a study of patients with non-ST-elevation MI showed no difference in mortality between men and women once adjustments were made for difference in age [13].

The proportions of cases included in the two registers differed substantially between regions (and also between hospitals). Some regions with a high proportion of matched cases, that is, more subjects with an acute MI hospitalized in a CCU/ICU, had fatality rates above the rates of those reporting fewer matched cases. This may at first seem unexpected. However, the results could reflect different organizations of the health care system and the hospitals. Some treatments and highly specialized care for high risk patients with a presumed worse prognosis will be concentrated to devoted hospitals. These hospitals will take care of more severe cases and might thus have higher mortality. Small number of cases in some hospitals can influence the result by chance. Referral of patients between different hospitals can influence the reporting of the patient to RIKS-HIA. More important, however, the observed differences in fatality rates may reflect differences in the ambition to include all cases in RIKS-HIA, or selecting relatively low risk patients, and/or avoiding referral of patients with dismal prognosis to the CCU/ICU. This may have implications when results and outcomes between hospitals and regions are compared. Similarly, results of different treatment regimens obtained from large randomized clinical trials in patients with acute coronary syndromes can be misleading and not readily generalized to daily clinical practice, as such trials often include low risk patients [14].

Both registers examined have important limitations. S-AMI has the disadvantage of a being based on more or less precise diagnoses set by the clinician. However, our previous validation of the register suggests this to be of minor importance [7]. There is also limited information about each patient in the register. No information regarding the severity of myocardial damage, complications, interventions or medication that can be related to outcome, is available. The lack of clinical data other than age, sex and other diagnoses given at the same time, limits the ability to properly estimate comorbidity and other factors that might influence the level of care and patient outcome.

In contrast, RIKS-HIA contains ample information about every included patient. However, data is (at present) entered manually over the internet, demanding extra time beyond documentation in patient records. The resources allocated for this varies between hospitals. Thus, different selection criteria for inclusion have been applied between hospitals introducing important bias in the data entered. The introduction of electronic patient records opens up new possibilities to extract structured information from patient records directly into national registers. This process has begun in Sweden but requires substantial efforts of adapting both the electronic patient records and the national registers for this task.

While the purpose of S-AMI is to cover all patients given a primary or secondary diagnosis of MI in the entire Swedish population, RIKS-HIA aims to evaluate adherence to guidelines in acute coronary care. Thus, there are important discrepancies between the registers even within the diagnosis of an acute MI, since only patients where it is justified from an ethical and health economical perspective to treat according to guidelines have so far been the main focus for RIKS-HIA. As shown in this study, the inclusion criteria vary substantially between hospitals. To be able to compare standards of care between different geographical regions by RIKS-HIA, our results indicate that a more universal inclusion in RIKS-HIA is warranted. It is encouraging to note that reports from Swedeheart suggest considerable improvement on this issue during the past years [3]. Another interesting issue to study would be drug utilisation and outcome. The Prescribed drug register contains complete data on all dispensed drugs in the country with unique identifiers of patients for >99% of all prescriptions since 2005 [15]. Linkage to S-AMI and Swedeheart in future studies could contribute importantly to our knowledge about treatment strategies after discharge from hospital.

Recognising these limitations, RIKS-HIA remains an important tool for studies of treatment effects, to detect rare complications, and changes in disease patterns. Notwithstanding the valuable information that can be obtained from registers such as RIKS-HIA, they complement population based registers (e.g. S-AMI). Thus, the combined use of S-AMI and RIKS-HIA, after necessary measurements to secure the personal integrity, may give a more correct description of patients with an acute MI.

ack.p: We thank the National Board of Health and Social Welfare for giving us access to the Swedish health registers, and Swedeheart for giving us access to RIKS-HIA. We are grateful to Professor Gisela Dahlquist for valuable support in planning of the study. We also thank Fereshte Ebrahim for good technical assistance in SAS programming.
